summary: A March 8, 2021 letter from defense attorney Laura A. Menninger to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, requesting discovery related to FBI FOIA releases to Radar Online concerning the Epstein investigation. The letter argues these documents are relevant to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense and questions the prosecution's prior statement about the FBI-New York Office's non-involvement in the earlier Florida investigation.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman representing Ghislaine Maxwell, who authored this discovery request letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in case 20 Cr. 330 (AJN), whose defense team is requesting discovery of FBI FOIA releases related to the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Subject of the FBI investigation referenced in the FOIA releases to Radar Online; described as Maxwell's alleged co-conspirator.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Judge referenced in the letter; the prosecution made a representation to her on October 7, 2020, regarding the prosecution team's involvement in the Florida investigation.

connections.description: Described as alleged co-conspirators in the context of the FBI investigation and prosecution.
Menninger is a defense attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman representing Maxwell, as evidenced by this discovery request on her behalf.

events.title: Prosecution Letter to Judge Nathan
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office represented to Judge Nathan that its prosecution team, including the FBI-New York Office, had no involvement in the Florida investigation of Epstein.

events.title: Requested Discovery Deadline
events.description: The defense requests the prosecution provide the requested FOIA-related discovery materials by this date, citing the rapidly approaching trial.

keyFacts: The defense is requesting all documents the FBI released to Radar Online (1,232 pages) regarding the investigation of Jeffrey Epstein, arguing they are relevant to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense.
The defense suggests witnesses may have conformed their testimony based on publicly released witness statements and police reports, making the timing of the FOIA releases material.

The defense challenges the prosecution's prior statement that the FBI-New York Office had no involvement in the Florida investigation, citing evidence it arranged interviews of New York witnesses from 2005-2010.
The letter reveals a prior FOIA lawsuit, Radar Online v. FBI, 17 Civ. 3956 (PGG), which resulted in the release of investigative materials about Epstein.
